column1: Vulnerable community identification using hate speech detection on social media, Information Processing and Management,
column6:
Information Processing & Management
Volume 57, Issue 3, May 2020, 102087
column22: content that attacks people based on their actual or perceived race, ethnicity, national origin, religion, sex, gender, sexual orientation, disability or disease
column50: Hate speech for Amahric. Annotation include targets such as ethnicity, politics, religion, and economic status. The data was collected using Facebook's Graph API. The study selected eleven Facebook public pages that were highly suspected of targeting ethnic groups for data collection. These pages included newspapers, broadcast media, individual politicians, activists, and different social network groups. The rationale behind their selection was that these communities commonly post on political and religious issues and share online information using Amharic as a national language. The data from these pages was rich enough to express people's ideas unreservedly and to locate the condition of the community.

column1: Are they Our Brothers? Analysis and Detection of Religious Hate Speech in the Arabic Twittersphere
column22: Although hate speech can be based on different protected characteristics, in this work our focus is on religious hate speech which we deﬁne as a speech that is insulting, offensive, or hurtful and is intended to incite hate, discrimination, or violence against an individual or a group of people on the basis of their religious affiliation.
column25: religious hate, non religious hate, unrelated
column50: Hate speech dataset for 6 religious grpuos. Religious name as lexicon. no slur in the keywords. retweets removed. Used CrowdFlower as crowdsourcing. Only Arabic native speakers considered. Three classes (hate, non-hate, and undecided) and 6 groups for religion (Muslims, Jews, Christians, Atheists, Sunnis, Shia, and/or other). The study found that Jews and Atheists had the highest percentages of tweets labeled as hate speech towards them, followed by Shia.

column1: L-HSAB: A Levantine Twitter Dataset for Hate Speech and Abusive Language
column22:
Normal tweets are those instances which
have no offensive, aggressive, insulting and
profanity content.
• Abusive tweets are those instances which
combine offensive, aggressive, insulting or
profanity content.
• Hate tweets are those instances that: (a) con-
tain an abusive language, (b) dedicate the of-
fensive, insulting, aggressive speech towards
a specific person or a group of people and
(c) demean or dehumanize that person or
that group of people based on their descrip-
tive identity (race, gender, religion, disability,
skin color, belief)
column50: Twitter is popular in Saudi, among the other Middle East countries. This work is for the Levantine dialect of Arabic. The dataset is called Levantine Hate Speech and ABusive (L-HSAB).  The annotation task requires labeling the tweets of L-HSAB dataset as Hate, Abusive or normal.

column1: T-HSAB: A Tunisian Hate Speech and Abusive Dataset
column22:
• Normal tweets are those instances with no offensive, aggressive, insulting and profanity content.

• Abusive tweets are those instances that combine offensive, aggressive, insulting or profanity content.

• Hate tweets are those instances that: (a) contain an abusive language, (b) dedicate the abusive language towards a specific person or a group of people and (c) demean or dehumanize that person or that group of people based on their descriptive identity (race, gender, religion, disability, skin color, belief).
column50: It is about hate speech in Tunisan Arabix. Used three annotators to label data (2 male and one female, university students) and calculated agreemtn between each pair of annotators, 97.963%, 83.11%, and 82.563%. Clasees, Hate, Abusive, normal

column25: political, personal, geopolitical, and religious hate.

column1: Hate Speech Detection in the Bengali Language: A Dataset and Its Baseline Evaluation
column18: Directlly present in paper + Youtube and Facebook guidelines
column22:
Hate speech is a sentence that dehumanizes one or multiple persons or a community. Dehumanizing can be done by comparing the person or community to an insect, object or a criminal. It can also be done by targeting a person based on their race, gender, physical and mental disability.
A sentence might contain slang or inappropriate language. But unless that slang dehumanizes a person or community, do not consider it to be hate speech.
If a comment does not dehumanize a person rather directly supports another idea that clearly dehumanizes a person or a community, this is considered hate speech.
If additional context is needed to understand that a comment is a hate speech, do not consider it to be one.
It does not matter if the stand that a hate speech comment takes is right or wrong. Because what is right or wrong is subjective. So if a sentence, without any outside context, dehumanizes a person or community, we considered that to be hate speech.
column41: No (Category of post is defined, not target group)

column1: Hate Speech and Offensive Language Detection in Bengali
column22:
-Hatespeech: Hate speech is a language used to express hatred toward a targeted individual or group or is intended to be derogatory, humiliating, or insulting to the group members based on attributes such as race, religion, ethnic origin, sexual orientation, disability, caste, geographic location or gender.
-Offensive: Offensive speech uses profanity, strongly impolite, rude, or vulgar language expressed with fighting or hurtful words to insult a targeted individual or group.
